What has peeved you lately? Report it here.
 
 My pet peeve of the hour: I was driving to town and was attempting to make a left turn at a stop sign when a driver in a big old SUV (who was tailgating) drove on the right shoulder to make a right turn, completely blocking my view. emoticon_mad
jim's trucking

I imagine a lot of pet peeves are related to driving.
 
 One of mine is people waiting 'til the last possible moment to get into the exit only lanes. They'll stop the non-exiting lanes with their signal flashing to get in line ahead of cars they should have been behind.
 
 Makes me want a Phalynx Gatling gun on the hood.

SUVs blocking view is a recent rant between my wife and I as well. I notice big rig and truck drivers don't generally block my view..intentionally, because they seem to know how to drive. The average SUV or minivan driver, doesn't seem to get it...or care.
 
 
 As is the "stopping traffic because I'm stupid and don't know where I'm going" that Jim mentions. Just reading these is getting me heated up.
 
 
 Today's pet peeve:
 
 Cigarette butts being thrown out of vehicles, especially when they hit my windshield, while lit.
 
 -Mach

My moan of the minute:
 
 Nursemaid weather forecasters on TV who spend so much time warning about the possibility of slipping on the ice, getting wet if you forget your raincoat, the dangers of spray from other vehicles when driving in the rain, etc., etc., that there's no time left to say anything about the actual weather.
 
 This is just a small part of my general grumble about living in a society under the supervision of self-appointed "official nannies".
jim's trucking

My moan of the minute:
 
 Nursemaid weather forecasters on TV who spend so much time warning about the possibility of slipping on the ice, getting wet if you forget your raincoat, the dangers of spray from other vehicles when driving in the rain, etc., etc., that there's no time left to say anything about the actual weather.
 
 This is just a small part of my general grumble about living in a society under the supervision of self-appointed "official nannies".
I agree with that one. It's all a part of their sales hype. News/Weather/Sports shows are just that...shows. 
 
 What really chaps my buns is how the shows are geared around the reporters and we have to look at them instead of just hearing their voices while viewing file footage or a weather map that covers the whole screen. 
 
 I don't really care who reads the news or who has the day off or who is out on assignment...just show the clips and tell me what's happenin'.

greg 79 f150

Ebay raider-traders who identify a niche market,bid up ever item in the category, then onsell at inflated prices emoticon_mad

 
 
 I think its called "sniping". I had never bought on ebay before. I bid on a set of factory truck service manuals that were rare and 28 years old. I was doing other things as I bid for two hours, but was always getting bumped by one other bidder, and ONLY he /she was bidding against me. ...
 
 After two hours of sparring, I finally bumped one dollar more at 30 seconds until closing and won. I ended up paying the original asking price. :( I finally got around to checking on the history of the person I out bid for two hours, the ONLY person bidding against me, and they came from the exact town and state, the product being bid on was from. Now, duh, what is the probablity of that one ??? :)
Alan Ryan

Continual harping (by the media) on the "risk" of doing or not doing something or other has become my annoyance of the minute.
 
 Since there is no human activity whatsoever that is entirely risk free, isn't it best to calculate the probabilities if you can, but when in doubt to damn the torpedoes ? 
 
 This is my temporary philosophy until patience gets the better of it.

JustineCredible

News papers which put all too much faith in computer spell-checks, which no longer rely on human proofreading to catch the all too common "An h" mistake.
 
 Such as "...an hospital." 
 
 ACK!!!! That just grates on my nerves! IT'S "a hospital," adding a consonant before an "h" word is NOT an English usage rule, it's more akin to the French rule of connecting "h" words with a preceding consonant via an apostrophe...as in "l'opital."

I agree with that one. It's all a part of their sales hype. News/Weather/Sports shows are just that...shows. 
 
 What really chaps my buns is how the shows are geared around the reporters and we have to look at them instead of just hearing their voices while viewing file footage or a weather map that covers the whole screen. 
 
 I don't really care who reads the news or who has the day off or who is out on assignment...just show the clips and tell me what's happenin'.

 
 
 Yes I agree, I don't see how people like some anchors better than others. I would like the station because of the people who gather the news. Also on the topic news stations that report on stories that have nothing to do with real news but boost ratings. Why so much on the runaway bride? That's not news? Maybe the first day when she was actually missing, but the whole next week they didn't need to have non-stop coverage of it, meanwhile a kid in our school died and it wasn't even on the local news.
zachvac

Drivers who go slow and then at a yellow light speed up and make it through the light but then you're stuck there. (used correct forms of all 3 words :))
 
 ditto on the one about going into the exit only lane at the very end. When we get off the beltway everyone is in a big long line waiting to get off and then there's the people who go by in the left lane and expect people to let them in at the end.
 
 
 Another driving pet peeve. In the Washington DC area we have HOV lanes (High Occupancy Vehicle) where if you have 2 or more people in your car you can use the lane but when there's a lot of traffic in the normal lanes cars will cheat and go in the HOV lanes but they go slow (like 40 with a 55 MPH speed limit) watching for a cop so they can get over. They still go faster than the regular lanes but they slow the HOV lanes WAY down (since people can usually go around 70-75).
Dzeron

 Like the government?
09dragonfly06

My peeves include:
 
 1. Wal-Mart--they have taken over everything! We have 4 wal-marts and 1 sams club all within 30 minutes of each other and everyone of them is so crowded that you can't even find a parking spot to walk to the radio shack that is in the same plaza!
 
 2. Restaurants/Establishments that allow smoking. Hello!! I don't particularly want my child breathing in your toxic fumes!
 
 3. People who drive while talking on the phone. Can you actually pay attention to the road with a cell phone to your ear?
 
 4. People who hack and hack and hack and then spit whatever they "hacked up" right near you while you are walking by.
 
 5. Public Restrooms (is there a mandatory do not clean law that I don't know about?).
 
 6. Opening my mailbox only to find that my newest "Rolling Stone" or "Parenting" magazine has been clearly mistreated by postal workers! I pay for those subscriptions and I would actually like to be able to read them without having to bend the pages out. (this happend today)
 
 7. Trying to have a decent night out over summer break when all of the high school kids with their shiny new drivers licenses think that they have the right to take up ALL parking spaces/blast loud music/burn the rubber off of their tires and shout and hoot like a bunch of XXXXXX.
 
 
 well that's about all for now :)
JustineCredible

People who don't know their French words (I believe it's l'hopital).

 ditto on the one about going into the exit only lane at the very end. When we get off the beltway everyone is in a big long line waiting to get off and then there's the people who go by in the left lane and expect people to let them in at the end.
 
 
 Another driving pet peeve. In the Washington DC area we have HOV lanes (High Occupancy Vehicle) where if you have 2 or more people in your car you can use the lane but when there's a lot of traffic in the normal lanes cars will cheat and go in the HOV lanes but they go slow (like 40 with a 55 MPH speed limit) watching for a cop so they can get over. They still go faster than the regular lanes but they slow the HOV lanes WAY down (since people can usually go around 70-75).

 
 
 
 Zach;
 
 I can completely sympathize!!! I used to live near DC and would have to commute daily. What truly angered me were those cars with "Diplomat" driver's licenses. They would drive as if they hadn't a care in the world, paying no attention whatsoever to traffic signals, HOV lanes on the beltway, or common courtesy. I was nearly hit head on by one on K Street. He must not have like the guy in front of him and decided to go around, cutting into my oncoming lane and nearly taking off half of my car! 
 These guys also double park on one-way streets, especially the really narrow ones, making it impossible to pass. Grrrrrrrr.....
 
 Another pet peeve of the roads are those who think the shoulder is a passing lane!
